title: Ticket #4292: Allow output from evictions to be not-spooled
description:
Here's the setup:
  • Running jobs as part of a DAG node.
  • We use periodic_remove to evict jobs that go over their memory limit.
  • Users want to retrieve stdout / err from these cases in order to figure out what the heck went wrong with their jobs.

Right now, if we set: 

WhenToTransferOutput = "ON_EXIT_OR_EVICT"

then the stdout is copied to the schedd into the spool and the spool is deleted. AFAICT, there's no way to get access to the job's incomplete output from a DAGMan post-script.

Traditionally, CMS has used a separate monitoring thread in its wrapper script to kill the job and make sure the output is returned; this drives me nuts because it replicates the procd.

I'd like to have a new job attribute, SpoolOnEvict (defaults to true if not set) which controls whether job output is moved to the spool on an eviction.

For CMS to be able to use this and not re-implement the current approach, this knob would need to go into 8.1.6. The implementation is fairly trivial if we can get agreement on the approach.

Brian
remarks:
2014-Apr-16 11:42:49 by bbockelm:
Discussed this on the phone 2 weeks ago with Todd. No objections were raised to the approach, although he asked me to verify that repeated condor_hold/condor_release on such jobs had predictable behavior.

Just did the testing this morning; there are no apparent issues in evicting the jobs multiple times. The output files from the second eviction overwrites the files from the first.

2014-Apr-16 14:04:56 by tannenba:
CODE REVIEW

Only feedback is to edit condor_submit to that folks can enter either 

   +SpoolOnEvict = True

or 

   spool_on_evict = True

or 

   SpoolOnEvict = True

just like all the other submit knobs. Once this is done this ticket can go to docpending state. Thanks for the patch!

2014-Apr-16 14:13:40 by bbockelm:
Hi Todd,

I'd be happy to do that - however, it makes the SpoolOnEvict knob relatively prominent (where I was thinking of it being a somewhat hidden knob for a specific use case). Are you OK with making this a first-class config knob? I assume that I somehow should add this to the manpage too.

Brian

2014-Apr-16 14:33:26 by tannenba:
Brian, re your first remark above: my concern wasn't about output files being overwritten, it was with intermediate (checkpoint) files. Imagine a job that writes out a self-checkpoint and has transfer files ON_EXIT_OR_EVICT. If SpoolOnEvict is True (as it always has been), then checkpoint file is written to spool and the job will resume where it left off upon restart because files in spool are a) written atomically, and b) sent to the execute node on restart. If a self-checkpointing job has SpoolOnEvict set to False, what happens on restart? This is what I wanted you to test... my guess is the job will restart from the beginning, right? If true, at the very least, the documentation should note that setting SpoolOnEvict will prevent user level checkpoint/resume and is only intended for debugging purposes?

Re the question about keeping SpoolOnEvict hidden or not - I'd vote for documenting it, but doing so in a way that clearly states the use case for this knob and what breaks/surprises are in store if you use it.

2014-Nov-04 13:36:07 by tannenba:
See #4679 for follow-on work to this.

As an aside, I am confused about why this ticket was moved (by TimT) from active to docpending without any of the code review changes being addressed, and then moved (by brian) from docpending to resolved without any documentation being added.
